courses.ronny_introduction:
For over 30 years, Ronny Hollenstein has worked as a trainer and coach with a focus on self-leadership, leadership, and communication. Trained by renowned figures such as Vera F. Birkenbihl, Shirzad Chamine, Maja Storch, and others, he has dedicated his career to helping people find their path and walk it authentically. His clients include leading figures from politics, business, and the public sector.
Originally from Vorarlberg and now based in Vienna, he has held several political roles and understands the challenge of conveying complex topics in a simple and clear way.
Since most outcomes in organizations are achieved through communication, improving it is especially close to Ronny’s heart. Better communication reduces transaction costs caused by misunderstandings, endless repetitions, unproductive debates about the unchangeable, and poorly resolved conflicts.
courses.ronny_quote: Good communication requires inner clarity, the courage to be direct, assertiveness, and methods for leading groups.

projects.title: Our Projects
projects.text: ALISMA brings young women in STEM together—at community events like the WAFF event, through inspiring workshops, and with our own diploma thesis competition. Our mini-books spark curiosity for technology among the youngest and break stereotypes. With campaigns, school projects, and role models, we create visibility, opportunities, and a strong network.

htlgirls.title: HTL Girls Community
htlgirls.text: The HTL Girls Community connects female students at Austrian HTLs, raises their visibility, and creates spaces for exchange, empowerment, and joint projects.

modernmen.title: Modern Men
modernmen.text: The Modern Men project supports young men through awareness, workshops, and training focused on emotional competence and gender equality.

empowering.title: EmpowerING – Get your title
empowering.text: EmpowerING makes graduates of technical studies visible and strengthens their recognition. With this initiative, we celebrate and inspire women in engineering.

mission.text:
Our mission is to strengthen and connect girls and women in STEM subjects and open doors to technical careers.
 We aim not only to inform, but to inspire—with role models, projects, and encounters that encourage and break stereotypes.
 ALISMA stands for a community where diversity is lived, successes are celebrated, and every young woman gets the support she needs for her path into technology and science.

alismaJoin.lead: Whether you’re an HTL student looking for like-minded peers, a role model who wants to inspire young women, or a school that wants to work with us on equal opportunities—we’re excited to meet you.
alismaJoin.body: Become part of a committed community that has each other’s back, shares knowledge, and opens new opportunities. Sign up for our newsletter, join our WhatsApp community, or volunteer—your contribution makes a difference.

lp_subtitle: ALISMA connects girls and young women in STEM, creates spaces for encounters and mutual support, and inspires new paths in technology and science.
wer_wir_sind_text: ALISMA is an association founded by six HTL students that empowers women and girls in STEM. We promote networking, dismantle prejudice, and create opportunities—from school workshops and role models to large community events. Our goal is to build a supportive community where everyone can contribute ideas, grow, and shape their future.

community_about.intro: Our community connects girls and women in STEM and provides a space for networking, mutual support, and shared growth. Here, learning, empowerment, and long-term friendships take shape.

banner.subtitle: A scroll story about how ALISMA strengthens girls and young women in STEM at Austria’s HTLs.

intro.title: By HTL girls. For HTL girls.
intro.body: ALISMA began as HTL Girls—a small group with a big mission: connect, empower, and make girls in technical education visible. Today, we are a growing community that opens doors, shares opportunities, and turns curiosity into confidence.

mission.title: Our mission
mission.body: We strengthen and connect girls and young women in STEM. We inform and inspire—with role models, projects, and encounters that encourage, break stereotypes, and celebrate achievements.

programs.title: What we do
programs.body: From community events and the WAFF showcase to school workshops, a diploma-thesis competition, and our mini-book series featuring real women in STEM—ALISMA creates places where learning meets belonging.

impact.title: Impact you can feel
impact.body: Hundreds of students reached, 974 voices from 11 HTLs, and many lasting connections. We make pathways into HTLs—and beyond—more visible and accessible.

together.title: Community—our strength
together.body: ALISMA is a safe, vibrant network across Austria’s HTLs. We foster diversity, strengthen emotional competence, and bring boys, teachers, and partners into constructive dialogue.

cta.title: Join in
cta.body: Become part of the ALISMA community: get updates, join our WhatsApp group, become a mentor, or support an event. Your voice can change paths.

hero.title: The HTL Community
hero.body: The HTL Community is a program by students for students. We connect, promote, and empower girls at technical schools—and show younger children and boys how diverse technology can be.
hero.imageAlt: HTL students in workshops and project scenes

why.title: Why a community?
why.body: Women are still underrepresented in technical schools and professions. Many feel alone or invisible. Our community breaks stereotypes, provides space for exchange, and makes women’s achievements visible.

offers.title: Our offerings
offers.body: The community thrives on many building blocks: community events, a WAFF event as a stage for role models and diploma theses, a diploma-thesis competition, school workshops & parent evenings, and mini-books that make technology playfully tangible for children.

impact.title: Looking back—what we’ve achieved
impact.body: From the first “Glow & Grow” event with 50 students to a survey with nearly 1,000 participants: networking works. Our results were presented nationwide in principals’ meetings.

vision.title: Our vision
vision.body: We want a strong, sustainable community: more girls at HTLs, visible female role models, girls’ officers at all HTLs, and lived diversity in technology.

join.title: Get involved—your place in the community
join.body: Whether as a student, role model, company, or supporter—you can be part of the movement. Together, we’re changing how girls experience technology.

hero.title: Modern Man – Being strong without a mask
hero.body: Modern Man is ALISMA’s program for boys at HTLs. It strengthens emotional competence, mental health, and respectful leadership—so young men in tech act with confidence, empathy, and as team players. It complements HTL Girls and builds bridges instead of fronts.
hero.imageAlt: HTL boys in workshop and project situations

why.title: Why Modern Man?
why.body: Because performance without self-regulation is costly. HTLs combine high pressure, project dynamics, and rigid role models. If you can’t read or express feelings, you lose focus, teamwork, and resilience. Modern strength means: understand emotions, respect boundaries, take responsibility—in projects, in class, and later at work.

problem.title: What’s the problem?
problem.body: Many boys learn early: be strong, don’t cry, show no weakness. Constantly suppressing emotions leads to depression or uncontrolled aggression. The consequences show up in society: young men are more often prosecuted or die by suicide. The roots lie in early upbringing and role models: girls may cry but should be quiet; boys should assert themselves, take what they want, show dominance. Later comes the pressure to be the “man of the house” and the breadwinner. Equality—e.g., equal pay—gives women appreciation and relieves pressure on men.

action.title: What exactly do we do?
action.body: Address taboos, create safe spaces, practice in real terms. We give young people language and tools for emotions, stress, and boundaries; we train respect, consent, and fair conflict resolution—straight from everyday situations. Authentic mentors like Kushtrim Alili build trust because they know the reality of the students. Result: less pressure, more agency.

goals.title: Goals
goals.body: Six focus areas that have immediate impact in the HTL day-to-day:
list: Emotional competence – perceive, name, and regulate feelings
Mental health – manage stress, improve sleep & focus
Respect & boundaries – communicate clearly, live consent, resolve fairly
Positive masculinity – combine performance with empathy
Allyship – cooperate constructively with girls, reduce sexism
Leadership – take responsibility in projects, class, and workplace

formats.title: Formats
formats.body: School-based, engaging, practice-oriented: a joint kick-off lowers barriers. Then come interactive workshops, peer mentoring, and mixed phases with HTL Girls. As a young mentor, Kushtrim Alili brings culturally sensitive perspectives, addresses taboos safely and respectfully—and shows practical paths for everyday life.
formats.note: Note: There is currently no fixed schedule.
list: Kick-off at the school (joint start, clear ground rules)
Workshop series with exercises & role plays
Mixed project phases (boys + girls)
Peer mentoring (students moderate parts themselves)
Impulses for teachers & parents (everyday tools)
Follow-up & community (office hours, mini challenges)

modules.title: Modules & content
modules.body: Compact building blocks that interlock and are directly applicable:
list: Emotion & language – read, name, and de-escalate feelings
Stress & sleep – tools for focus, recovery, exam periods
Respect & consent – recognize boundaries, communicate clearly
Masculinity & media – reflect on roles instead of copying them
Team & conflict resolution – argue fairly, decide cleanly
Leadership & responsibility – be a role model in project routines

didactics.title: Didactics & attitude
didactics.body: Strength-based, without finger-wagging—short, concrete, from real situations. Safe spaces: voluntariness, respect, no shaming. Trauma-informed and culturally sensitive. Modern Man is not therapy; if needed, we refer to professional services.
list: Interactive & exercise-based instead of frontal lecturing
Reality-based: cases from school, projects, and apprenticeships
Safe framework: clear rules, feedback culture
Cultural sensitivity & addressing taboos with care
Clear referral paths to counseling services if necessary

impact.title: Impact & evaluation
impact.body: We measure knowledge, attitude, and behavior—not just sentiment. Checks before/after modules, feedback from students & teachers, and observations in project routines show impact.
list: Scales for emotion knowledge, stress competence, respectful behavior
Reduction of sexist language/cyberbullying (anonymized)
Better class climate & collaboration in projects
Number of peers who moderate units themselves

targetGroups.title: Target groups
targetGroups.body: Modern Man is aimed at HTL boys (13–19) and strengthens soft skills for school, projects, and work. Schools gain a more stable class climate; parents see a more reflective image of masculinity. Companies benefit from young talent with teamwork and leadership potential.
list: HTL boys (13–19) – everyday soft skills
Teachers & schools – better climate, fewer conflicts
Parents & public – modern image of masculinity
Companies – teamwork & leadership maturity

kushtrim.subtitle: Trustworthy, approachable, culturally sensitive: he speaks to young people at eye level.

bio.name: Kushtrim Alili
bio.origin: Born in North Macedonia, Albanian background
bio.context: Raised with collectivist influences—the collective counts, yet individual needs need space.

quotes: It’s important to break taboos and create a society where every person is born with equal rights and opportunities.
kushtrim.about: Kushtrim supports Modern Man workshops on emotional competence, respect, and mental health. His background and young age build trust—he knows the topics firsthand and shows how to reduce pressure: express feelings safely, respect boundaries, take responsibility in the team.

hero.title: EmpowerING – Get Your Title
hero.body: EmpowerING makes the achievements of women engineers in the HTL environment visible, strengthens recognition, and connects people and opportunities. The focus: connect, make visible, recognize.
hero.imageAlt: Women engineers in project and presentation situations at HTL

what.title: What it’s about
what.body: EmpowerING is a concept that makes the achievements of women engineers more visible and strengthens recognition. It builds on connection and exchange so that successes are seen, shared, and carried forward.

why.title: Why visibility matters
why.body: Visibility creates opportunity. Those who are seen are invited, supported, and remembered. People recommend those they know—targeted visibility is the key to recognition.

how.title: How the story is told
how.intro: The page guides you step by step—from the why to the impact.
list: Connect: link people, paths, and opportunities.
Make visible: tell, show, and honor achievements.
Strengthen recognition: record successes and carry them forward.

who.title: For whom
who.body: For HTL students and graduates—and everyone who wants to support the visibility and recognition of technical achievements in schools, families, companies, and the public.

stories.title: Stories that stay
stories.body: Short portraits and voices show what’s possible when achievement is seen. Each story gives courage to write the next one.

cta.title: Become part of the story now
cta.body: Everyone who wants to help shape it is invited. Visibility grows when many contribute.

partners.title: Stronger together
partners.body: Supporters carry visibility with them. That’s how a movement grows from individual successes.
